sp.p: No occasion?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Certainly not, i' faith.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: How so, I wonder?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: You shall soon know.You shall soon know: Madame Dacier suggests that Chremes is prevented by his wife's coming from making a proposal to advance the money himself, on the supposition that it will be a lucrative speculation. This notion is contradicted by Colman, who adds the following note from Eugraphius: "Syrus pretends to have concerted this plot against Menedemus, in order to trick him out of some money to be given to Clinia's supposed mistress. Chremes, however, does not approve of this: yet it serves to carry on the plot; for when Antiphila proves afterward to be the daughter of Chremes, he necessarily becomes the debtor of Bacchis, and is obliged to lay down the sum for which he imagines his daughter is pledged."

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Stop, stop; what is the reason that there is such a great noise at our door ? They retire out of sight.

div2.p: Enter SOSTRATA and a NURSE in haste from the house of CHREMES, and CHREMES and SYRUS on the other side of the stage unperceived.
Sos. holding up a ring and examining it. Unless my fancy deceives me, surely this is the ring which I suspect it to be, the same with which my daughter was exposed.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: apart. Syrus, what is the meaning of these expressions ?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Nurse, how is it? Does it not seem to you the same?

sp.speaker: NUR.
sp.p: As for me, I said it was the same the very instant that you showed it me.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: But have you now examined it thoroughly, my dear nurse?

sp.speaker: NUR.
sp.p: Thoroughly.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Then go in-doors at once, and if she has now done bathing, bring me word. I'll wait here in the mean time for my husband.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: apart. She wants you, see what it is she wants; she is in a serious mood, I don't know why; it is not without a cause----I fear what it may be.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What it may be? I' faith, she'll now surely be announcing some important trifle, with a great parade.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: turning round. Ha! my husband!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Ha! my wife !

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I was looking for you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me what you want.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: In the first place, this I beg of you, not to believe that I have ventured to do any thing contrary to your commands.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Would you have me believe you in this, although so incredible? Well, I will believe you.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: aside. This excuse portends I know not what offense.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Do you remember me being pregnant, and yourself declaring to me, most peremptorily, that if I should bring forth a girl, you would not have it brought up.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I know what you have done, you have brought it up.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: aside. Such is the fact, I'm sure: my young master has gained a lossHas gained a loss: He alludes to Clitipho, who, by the discovery of his sister, would not come in for such a large share of his father's property, and would consequently, as Syrus observes, gain a loss. in consequence.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Not at all; but there was here an elderly woman of Corinth, of no indifferent character; to her I gave it to be exposed.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: O Jupiter! that there should be such extreme folly in a person's mind.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Alas! what have I done ?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: And do you ask the question?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: If I have acted wrong, my dear Chremes, I have done so in ignorance.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: This, indeed, I know for certain, even if you were to deny it, that in every thing you both speak and act ignorantly and foolishly: how many blunders you disclose in this single affair! For, in the first place, then, if you had been disposed to obey my orders, the child ought to have been dispatched; you ought not in words to have feigned her death, and in reality to have left hopes of her surviving. But that I pass over; compassion, maternal affection, I allow it. But how finely you did provide for the future! What was your meaning ? Do reflect. It's clear, beyond a doubt, that your daughter was betrayed by you to this old woman, either that through you she might make a living by her, or that she might be sold in open market as a slave. I suppose you reasoned thus: " any thing is enough, if only her life is saved :" what are you to do with those who understand neither law, nor right and justice? Be it for better or for worse, be it for them or against them, they see nothing except just what they please.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: My dear Chremes, I have done wrong, I own ; I am convinced. Now this I beg of you; inasmuch as you are more advanced in years than I, be so much the more ready to forgive; so that your justice may be some protection for my weakness.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll readily forgive you doing this, of course; but, Sostrata, my easy temper prompts you to do amiss. But, whatever this circumstance is, by reason of which this was begun upon, proceed to tell it.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: As we women are all foolishly and wretchedly superstitious, when I delivered the child to her to be exposed, I drew a ring from off my finger, and ordered her to expose it, together with the child; that if she should die, she might not be withoutThat she might not be without)--Ver 652. Madame Dacier observes upon this passage, that the ancients thought themselves guilty of a heinous offense if they suffered their children to die without having bestowed on them some of their property; it was consequently the custom of the women, before exposing children, to attach to them some jewel or trinket among their clothes, hoping thereby to avoid incurring the guilt above mentioned, and to ease their consciences. some portion of our possessions.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: That was right; thereby you proved the saving of yourself and her.Saving of yourself and her: Madame Dacier says that the meaning of this passage is this: Chremes tells his wife that by having given this ring, she has done two good acts instead of one--she has both cleared her conscience and saved the child; for had there been no ring or token exposed with the infant, the finder would not have been at the trouble of taking care of it, but might have left it to perish, never suspecting it would be inquired after, or himself liberally rewarded for having preserved it.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: holding out the ring. This is that ring.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Whence did you get it?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: From the young woman whom Bacchis brought here with her.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: aside. Ha!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What does she say?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: She gave it me to keep for her, while she went to bathe. At first I paid no attention to it; but after I looked at it, I at once recognized it, and came running to you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What do you suspect now, or have you discovered, relative to her ?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I don't know; unless you inquire of herself whence she got it, if that can possibly be discovered.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: aside. I'm undone! I see more hopesI see more hopes: Syrus is now alarmed that Antiphila should so soon be acknowledged as the daughter of Chremes, lest he may lose the opportunity of obtaining the money, and be punished as well, in case the imposition is detected, and Bacchis discovered to be the mistress of Clitipho and not of Clinia. from this incident than I desire. If it is so, she certainly must be ours.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Is this woman living to whom you delivered the child?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What account did she bring you at the time?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: That she had done as I had ordered her.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me what is the woman's name, that she may be inquired after.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Philtere.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: aside. 'Tis the very same. It's a wonder if she isn't found, and I lost.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Sostrata, follow me this way in-doors.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: How much beyond my hopes has this matter turned out! How dreadfully afraid I was, Chremes, that you would now be of feelings as unrelenting as formerly you were on exposing the child.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Many a time a man can not beA man can not be: This he says by way of palliating the cruelty he was guilty of in his orders to have the child put to death. such as he would be, if circumstances do not admit of it. Time has now so brought it about, that I should be glad of a daughter; formerly I wished for nothing less. CHREMES and SOSTRATA go into the house.)

div2.stage: SYRUS alone.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Unless my fancy deceives me,Unless my fancy deceives me: "Nisi me animus fallit." He comically repeats the very same words with which Sostrata commenced in the last Scene. retributionRetribution: "Infortunium!" was the name by which the slaves commonly denoted a beating. Colman has the following remark here: " Madame Dacier, and most of the later critics who have implicitly followed her, tell us that in the interval between the third and fourth Acts, Syrus has been present at the interview between Chremes and Antiphila within. The only difficulty in this doctrine is how to reconcile it to the apparent ignorance of Syrus, which he discovers at the entrance of Clinia. But this objection, says she, is easily answered. Syrus having partly heard Antiphila's story, and finding things likely to take an unfavorable turn, retires, to consider what is best to be done. But surely this is a most unnatural impatience at so critical a conjuncture; and, after all, would it not be better to take up the matter just where Terence has left it, and to suppose that Syrus knew nothing more of the affair than what might be collected from the late conversation between Chremes and Sostrata, at which we know he was present ? This at once accounts for his apprehensions, which he betrayed even during that Scene, as well as for his imperfect knowledge of the real state of the case, till apprised of the whole by Clinia." will not be very far off from me; so much by this incident are my forces now utterly driven into straits; unless I contrive by some means that the old man mayn't come to know that this damsel is his son's mistress. For as to entertaining any hopes about the money, or supposing I could cajole him, it's useless; I shall be sufficient triumphant, if I'm allowed to escape with my sides covered.With my sides covered: He most probably alludes to the custom of tying up the slaves by their hands, after stripping them naked, when of course their " latera" or " sides" would be exposed, and come in for a share of the lashes. I'm vexed that such a tempting morsel has been so suddenly snatched away from my jaws. What am I to do? Or what shall I devise? I must begin upon my plan over again. Nothing is so difficult, but that it may be found out by seeking. What now if I set about it after this fashion. He considers. That's of no use. What, if after this fashion? I effect just about the same. But this I think will do. It can not. Yes! excellent. Bravo! I've found out the best of all--I' faith, I do believe that after all I shall lay hold of this same run-away money.Runaway money: "Fugitivum argentum." Madame Dacier suggests that this is a bad translation of the words of Menander, which were "a)postre/yein to\n drape/tan xruso\n," where " "xruso\s" signified both " gold" and the name of a slave.

div2.stage: Enter CLINIA at the other side of the stage.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: to himself. Nothing can possibly henceforth befall me of such consequence as to cause me uneasiness; so extreme is this joy that has surprised me. Now then I shall give myself up entirely to my father, to be more frugal than even he could wish.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: apart. I wasn't mistaken; she has been discovered, so far as I understand from these words of his. Acvancing. I am rejoiced that this matter has turned out for you so much to your wish.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: O my dear Syrus, have you heard of it, pray?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: How shouldn't I, when I was present all the while ?

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: Did you ever hear of any thing falling out so fortunately for any one?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: And, so may the Gods prosper me, I do not now rejoice so much on my own account as hers, whom I know to be deserving of any honor.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I believe it: but now, Clinia, come, attend to me in my turn. For your friend's business as well,--it must be seen to--that it is placed in a state of security, lest the old gentleman should now come to know any thing about his mistress.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: O Jupiter!

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Do be quiet.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: My Antiphila will be mine.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Do you still interrupt me thus ?

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: What can I do? My dear Syrus, I'm transported with joy! Do bear with me.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I' faith, I really do bear with you.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: We are blest with the life of the Gods.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I'm taking pains to no purpose, I doubt.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: Speak; I hear you.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But still you'll not mind it.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: This must be seen to, I say, that your friend's business as well is placed in a state of security. For if you now go away from us, and leave Bacchis here, our old man will immediately come to know that she is Clitipho's mistress; if you take her away with you, it will be concealed just as much as it has been hitherto concealed.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
SYRUS
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: What can I say? What excuse can I make?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Nay, I don't want you to dissemble; tell him the whole case just as it really is.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: What is it you say ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I bid you do this; tell him that you are in love with her, and want her for a wife: that this Bacchis is Clitipho's mistress.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: You require a thing that is fair and reasonable, and easy to be done. And I suppose, then, you would have me request my father to keep it a secret from your old man.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: On the contrary; to tell him directly the matter just as it is.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: What? Are you quite in your senses or sober? Why, you were for ruining him outright. For how could he be in a state of security ? Tell me that.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: For my part, I yield the palm to this device. Here I do pride myself exultingly, in having in myself such exquisite resources, and power of address so great, as to deceive them both by telling the truth: so that when your old man tells ours that she is his son's mistress, he'll still not believe him.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: But yet, by these means you again cut off all hopes of my marriage; for as long as Chremes believes that she is my mistress, he'll not give me his daughter. Perhaps you care little what becomes of me, so long as you provide for him.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: What the plague, do you suppose I want this pretense to be kept up for an age ? 'Tis but for a single day, only till I have secured the money: you be quiet; I ask no more.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: Is that sufficient? If his father should come to know of it, pray, what then?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: What if I have recourse to those who say, " What now if the sky were to fall?"If the sky were to fall: He means those who create unnecessary difficulties in their imagination. Colman quotes the following remark from Patrick: "There is a remarkable passage in Arrian's Account of Alexander, lib. iv., where he tells us that some embassadors from the Celtae, being asked by Alexander what in the world they dreaded most, answered, ' That they feared lest the sky should fall [upon them].' Alexander, who expected to hear himself named, was surprised at an answer which signified that they thought themselves beyond the reach of all human power, plainly implying that nothing could hurt them, unless he would suppose impossibilities, or a total destruction of nature." Aristotle, in his Physics, B. iv., informs us that it was the early notion of ignorant nations that the sky was supported on the shoulders of Atlas, and that when he let go of it, it would fall.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: I'm afraid to go about it.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: You, afraid! As if it was not in your power to clear yourself at any time you like, and discover the whole matter.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: Well, well; let Bacchis be brought over to our house.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Capital! she is coming out of doors.

div2.stage: Enter BACCHIS and PHRYGIA, from the house of CHREMES.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: pretending not to see CLINIA and SYRUS. To a very fine purpose,To a very fine purpose: " Satis pol proterve," &c. C. Laelius was said to have assisted Terence in the composition of his Plays, and in confirmation of this, the following story is told by Cornelius Nepos: " C. Laelius, happening to pass the Matronalia [a Festival on the first of March, when the husband, for once in the year, was bound to obey the wife] at his villa near Puteoli, was told that dinner was waiting, but still neglected the summons. At last, when he made his appearance, he excused himself by saying that he had been in a particular vein of composition, and quoted certain lines which occur in the Heautontimorumenos, namely, those beginning ' Satis pol proterve me Syri promissa hue induxerunt.'" upon my faith, have the promises of Syrus brought me hither, who agreed to lend me ten minae. If now he deceives me, oft as he may entreat me to come, he shall come in vain. Or else, when I've promised to come, and fixed the time, when he has carried word back for certain, and Clitipho is on the stretch of expectation, I'll disappoint him and not come. Syrus will make atonement to me with his back.

sp.speaker: CLINIA
sp.p: apart, to SYRUS. She promises you very fairly.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: to CLINIA. But do you think she is in jest? She'll do it, if I don't take care.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: aside. They're asleepThey're asleep: "Dormiunt." This is clearly used figuratively, though Hedelin interprets it literally.--I'faith, I'll rouse them. Aloud. My dear Phrygia, did you hear about the country-seat of Charinus, which that man was showing us just now ?

sp.speaker: PHRYGIA
sp.p: I heard of it.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: aloud. That it was the next to the farm here on the right-hand side.Farm here on the right-hand side: Cooke suggests that the Poet makes Bacchis call the house of Charinus "villa," and that of Chremes "fundus" (which signifies " a farm-house," or "farm"), for the purpose of exalting the one and depreciating the other in the hearing of Syrus.

sp.speaker: PHRYGIA
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: aloud. Run thither post-haste; the Captain is keeping the feast of BacchusThe feast of Bacchus: This passage goes far to prove that the Dionysia here mentioned as being celebrated, were those ka/t) a\grous, or the " rural Dionysia." at his house.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: apart. What is she going to be at?

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: aloud. Tell him I am here very much against my inclination, and am detained; but that by some means or other I'll give them the slip and come to him. PHRYGIA moves.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: coming forward. Upon my faith, I'm ruined! Bacchis, stay, stay; prithee, where are you sending her ? Order her to stop.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: to PHRYGIA. Be off.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Why, the money's ready.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: Why, then I'll stay. PHRYGIA returns.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: And it will be given you presently.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: Just when you please; do I press you ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But do you know what you are to do, pray?

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: You must now go over to the house of Menedemus, and your equipage must be taken over thither.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: What scheme are you upon, you rascal?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: What, I ? Coining money to give you.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: Do you think me a proper person for you to play upon ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: It's not without a purpose.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: pointing to the house. Why, have I any business then with you here?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: O no; I'm only going to give you what's your own.

sp.speaker: BACCHIS.
sp.p: Then let's be going.Let's be going: Colman here remarks to the following effect: "There is some difficulty in this and the next speech in the original, and the Commentators have been puzzled to make sense of them. It seems to me that the Poet's intention is no more than this: Bacchis expresses some reluctance to act under the direction of Syrus, but is at length prevailed on, finding that he can by those means contrive to pay her the money which he has promised her."

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Follow this way. Goes to the door of MENEDIEMUS, and calls. Ho there! Dromo. Enter DROMO from the house.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: Who is it wants me ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Syrus.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Take over all the attendants of Bacchis to your house here immediately.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Ask no questions. Let them take what they brought here with them. The old gentleman will hope his expenses are lightened by their departure; for sure he little knows how much loss this trifling gain will bring him. You, Dromo, if you are wise, know nothing of what you do know.

sp.speaker: DROMO
sp.p: You shall own that I'm dumb. CLINIA, BACCHIS, and PHRYGIA go into the house of MENEDEMUS, and DROMO follows with BACCHIS'S retinue and baggage.

div2.stage: Enter CHREMES from his house.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to himself So may the Deities prosper me, I am now concerned for the fate of Menedemus, that so great a misfortune should have befallen him. To be maintaining that woman with such a retinue! Although I am well aware he'll not be sensible of it for some days to come, his son was so greatly missed by him; but when he sees such a vast expense incurred by him every day at home, and no limit to it, he'll wish that this son would leave him a second time. See--here comes Syrus most opportunely.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: to himself, as he comes forward. Why delay to accost him?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Syrus.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: How go matters ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I've been wishing for some time for you to be thrown in my way.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: YOU seem, then, to have effected something, I know not what, with the old gentleman.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: As to what we were talking of a short time since? No sooner said than done.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: In real earnest ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: In real.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Upon my faith, I can not forbear patting your head for it. Come here, Syrus; I'll do you some good turn for this matter, and with pleasure. Patting his head.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But if you knew how cleverly it came into my head----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Pshaw! Do you boast because it has turned out according to your wishes

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: On my word, not I, indeed; I am telling the truth.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me how it is.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Clinia has told Menedemus, that this Bacchis is your Clitipho's mistress, and that he has taken her thither with him in order that you might not come to know of it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Tell me, please, what you think of it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Extremely good, I declare.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Why yes, pretty fair. But listen, what a piece of policy still remains. He is then to say that he has seen your daughter--that her beauty charmed him as soon as he beheld her; and that he desires her for a wife.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What, her that has just been discovered ?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: The same; and, in fact, he'll request that she may be asked for.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For what purpose, Syrus? For I don't altogether comprehend it.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: O dear, you are so dull.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Perhaps so.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Money will be given him for the wedding--with which golden trinkets and clothes----do you understand me?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: To buy them----?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: But I neither give nor betroth my daughter to him.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why, do you ask me? To a fellow----

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Just as you please. I don't mean that in reality you should give her to him, but that you should pretend it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Pretending is not in my way; do you mix up these plots of yours, so as not to mix me up in them. Do you think that I'll betroth my daughter to a person to whom I will not marry her?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I imagined so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: It might have been cleverly managed; and I under-took this affair for the very reason, that a short time since you so urgently requested it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I believe you.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But for my part, Chremes, I take it well and good, either way.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: But still, I especially wish you to do your best for it to be brought about; but in some other way.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: It shall be done: some other method must be thought of; but as to what I was telling you of,--about the money which she owes to Bacchis,--that must now be repaid her. And you will not, of course, now be having recourse to this method; "What have I to do with it? Was it lent to me? Did I give any orders? Had she the power to pawn my daughter without my consent?" They quote that saying, Chremes, with good reason, " Riorous lawRigorous law: Cicero mentions the same proverb in his work De Officiis, B. i., ch. 10, substituting the word "injuria" for " malitia." "' Extreme law, extreme injustice,' is now become a stale proverb in discourse." The same sentiment is found in the Fragments of Menander. is often rigorous injustice."

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I will not do so.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: On the contrary, though others were at liberty, you are not at liberty; all think that you are in good and very easy circumstances.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nay rather, I'll at once carry it to her myself.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Why no; request your son in preference.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Why, because the suspicion of being in love with her has been transferred to him with Menedemus.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
CHREMES
sp.p: I'll bring it. Goes into his house.

div2.stage: Enter CLITIPHO.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: to himself. There is nothing so easy but that it becomes difficult when you do it with reluctance. As this walk of mine, for instance, though not fatiguing, it has reduced me to weariness. And now I dread nothing more than that I should be packed off somewhere hence once again, that I may not have access to Bacchis. May then all the Gods and Goddesses, as many as exist, confound you, Syrus, with these stratagems and plots of yours. You are always devising something of this kind, by means of which to torture me.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Will you not away with you--to where you deserve? How nearly had your forwardness proved my ruin!

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Upon my faith, I wish it had been so; just what you deserve.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Deserve? How so? Really, I'm glad that I've heard this from you before you had the money which I was just going to give you.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What then would you have me to say to you? You've made a fool of me; brought my mistress hither, whom I'm not allowed to touch----

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Well, I'm not angry then. But do you know where Bacchis is just now?

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: At our house.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Where then?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: At Clinia's.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: I'm ruined!

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Be of good heart; you shall presently carry to her the money that you promised her.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: You do prate away.--Where from?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: From your own father.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Perhaps you are joking with me.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: The thing itself will prove it.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Indeed, then, I am a lucky man. Syrus, I do love you from my heart.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But your father's coming out. Take care not to express surprise at any thing, for what reason it is done; give way at the proper moment; do what he orders, and say but little.

div2.stage: Enter CHREMES from the house, with a bag of money.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Where's Clitipho now?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: aside to CLITIPHO. Say--here I am.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Here am I.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to SYRUS. Have you told him how it is?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I've told him pretty well every thing.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Take this money, and carry it. Holding out the bag.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: aside to CLITIPHO. Go--why do you stand still, you stone; why don't you take it?

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Very well, give it me. Receives the bag.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: to CLITIPHO. Follow me this way directly. To CHREMES. You in the mean while will wait here for us till we return; for there's no occasion for us to stay there long. CLITIPHO and SYRUS go into the house of MENEDEMUS.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to himself. My daughter, in fact, has now had ten minae from me, which I consider as paid for her board; another ten will follow these for clothes; and then she will require two talents for her portion. How many things, both just and unjust, are sanctioned by custom!Are sanctioned by custom: He inveighs, perhaps justly, against the tyranny of custom; but in selecting this occasion for doing so, he does not manifest any great affection for his newly-found daughter. Now I'm obliged, neglecting my business, to look out for some one on whom to bestow my property, that has been acquired by my labor.

div2.stage: Enter MENEDEMUS from his house.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: to CLINIA within. My son, I now think myself the happiest of all men, since I find that you have returned to a rational mode of life.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: aside. How much he is mistaken!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Chremes, you are the very person I wanted; preserve, so far as in you lies, my son, myself, and my family.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Tell me what you would have me do.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: You have this day found a daughter.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Clinia wishes her to be given him for a wife.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Prithee, what kind of a person are you?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Have you already forgotten what passed between us, concerning a scheme, that by that method some money might be got out of you?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: That self-same thing they are now about.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What do you tell me, Chremes? Why surely, this Courtesan, who is at my house, is Clitipho's mistress.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: So they say, and you believe it all; and they say that he is desirous of a wife, in order that, when I have betrothed her, you may give him money, with which to provide gold trinkets and clothing, and other things that are requisite.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: That is it, no doubt; that money will be given to his mistress.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Of course it is to be given.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Alas! in vain then, unhappy man, have I been overjoyed; still however, I had rather any thing than be deprived of him. What answer now shall I report from you, Chremes, so that he may not perceive that I have found it out, and take it to heart?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: To heart, indeed! you are too indulgent to him, Menedemus.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Let me go on; I have now begun: assist me in this throughout, Chremes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Say then, that you have seen me, and have treated about the marriage.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I'll say so--what then?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: That I will do every thing; that as a son-in-law he meets my approbation; in fine, too, if you like, tell him also that she has been promised him.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Well, that's what I wanted----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: That he may the sooner ask of you, and you may as soon as possible give him what you wish.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: It is my wish.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Assuredly, before very long, according as I view this matter, you'll have enough of him. But, however that may be, if you are wise, you'll give to him cautiously, and a little at a time.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I'll do so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Go in-doors and see how much he requires. I shall be at home, if you should want me for any thing.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I certainly do want you; for I shall let you know whatever I do. They go into their respective houses.

div2.stage: Enter MENEDEMUS from his house.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: to himself. I am quite aware that I am not so overwise, or so very quick-sighted; but this assistant, prompter, and directorAssistant, prompter, and director: The three terms here used are borrowed from the stage. "Adjutor" was the person who assisted the performers either by voice or gesture; "monitor" was the prompter; and "praemonstrator" was the person who in the rehearsal trained the actor in his part. of mine, Chremes, outdoes me in that. Any one of those epithets which are applied to a fool is suited to myself, such as dolt, post, ass,Dolt post, ass: There is a similar passage in the Bacchides of Plautus, 1. 1087. "Whoever there are in any place whatsoever, whoever have been, and whoever shall be in time to come, fools, blockheads, idiots, dolts, sots, oafs, lubbers, I singly by far exceed them all in folly and absurd ways." lump of lead; to him not one can apply; his stupidity surpasses them all. Enter CHREMES, speaking to SOSTRATA within.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Hold now, do, wife, leave off dinning the Gods with thanksgivings that your daughter has been discovered; unless you judge of them by your own disposition, and think that they understand nothing, unless the same thing has been told them a hundred times. But, in the mean time, why does my son linger there so long with Syrus?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What persons do you say are lingering?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Ha! Menedemus, you have come opportunely. Tell me, have you told Clinia what I said?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Every thing.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: He began to rejoice, just like people do who wish to be married.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: laughing. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why are you laughing?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: The sly tricks of my servant, Syrus, just came into my mind.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Did they?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: The rogue can even mould the countenances of people.Mould the countenances of people--Ver. 887. He means that Syrus not only lays his plots well, but teaches the performers to put on countenances suitable to the several parts they are to act.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: That my son is pretending that he is overjoyed, is it that you mean?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Just so. Laughing.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: The very same thing came into my mind.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: A crafty knave!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Still more would you think such to be the fact, if you knew more.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do you say so?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Do you give attention then?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Just stop--first I want to know this, what money you have squandered; for when you told your son that she was promised, of course Dromo would at once throw in a word that golden jewels, clothes, and attendants would be needed for the bride, in order that you might give the money.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: How, no?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: No, I tell you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nor yet your son himself?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Not in the slightest, Chremes. He was only the more pressing on this one point, that the match might be concluded to-day.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: You say what's surprising. What did my servant Syrus do? Didn't even he say any thing?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For what reason, I don't know.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: For my part, I wonder at that, when you know other things so well. But this same Syrus has moulded your son,Has moulded your son: "Mire finxit." He sarcastically uses the same word, "fingo," which Chremes himself employed in 1. 887. too, to such perfection, that there could not be even the slightest suspicion that she is Clinia's mistress!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Not to mention, then, their kissing and embracing; that I count nothing.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What more could be done to carry on the cheat?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Only listen. In the inner part of my house there is a certain room at the back; into this a bed was brought, and was made up with bed-clothes.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What took place after this?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: No sooner said than done, thither went Clitipho.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Alone.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'm alarmed.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Bacchis followed directly.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Alone.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'm undone!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: When they had gone into the room, they shut the door.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Well--did Clinia see all this going on?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: How shouldn't he? He was with me.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Bacchis is my son's mistress, Menedemus I'm undone.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I have hardly substance to suffice for ten days.Substance to suffice for ten days: "Familia" here means "property," as producing sustenance. Colman, however, has translated the passage: "Mine is scarce a ten-days' family."

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What! are you alarmed at it, because he is paying attention to his friend?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: His "she-friend" rather.His she-friend rather: Menedemus speaks of "amico," a male friend, which Chremes plays upon by saying amicae," which literally meant a she-friend, and was the usual name by which decent people called a mistress.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: If he really is paying it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Is it a matter of doubt to you? Do you suppose that there is any person of so accommodating and tame a spirit as to suffer his own mistress, himself looking on, to----

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: chuckling and speaking ironically. Why not? That I may be imposed upon the more easily.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do you laugh at me? You have good reason. How angry I now am with myself! How many things gave proof, whereby, had I not been a stone, I might have been fully sensible of this? What was it I saw? Alas! wretch that I am! But assuredly they shall not escape my vengeance if I live; for this instant----

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Can you not contain yourself? Have you no respect for yourself? Am I not a sufficient example to you?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: For very anger, Menedemus, I am not myself.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: For you to talk in that manner! Is it not a shame for you to be giving advice to others, to show wisdom abroad and yet be able to do nothing for yourself?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: That which you said I failed to do: make him sensible that you are his father; make him venture to intrust every thing to you, to seek and to ask of you; so that he may look for no other resources and forsake you.And forsake you: Madame Dacier observes here, that one of the great beauties of this Scene consists in Chremes retorting on Menedemus the very advice given by himself at the beginning of the Play.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nay, I had much rather he would go any where in the world, than by his debaucheries here reduce his father to beggary! For if I go on supplying his extravagance, Menedemus, in that case my circumstances will undoubtedly be soon reduced to the level of your rake.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
CHREMES
sp.p: Ah! you don't know how vexed I am.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Just as you please. What about that which I desire--that she may be married to my son? Unless there is any other step that you would prefer.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: On the contrary, both the son-in-law and the connection are to my taste.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What portion shall I say that you have named for your daughter? Why are you silent?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Portion?

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I say so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Chremes, don't be at all afraid to speak, if it is but a small one. The portion is no consideration at all with us.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I did think that two talents were sufficient, according to my means. But if you wish me to be saved, and my estate and my son, you must say to this effect, that I have settled all my property on her as her portion.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What scheme are you upon?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Pretend that you wonder at this, and at the same time ask him the reason why I do so.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why, really, I can't conceive the reason for your doing so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why do I do so? To check his feelings, which are now hurried away by luxury and wantonness, and to bring him down so as not to know which way to turn himself.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What is your design?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Let me alone, and give me leave to have my own way in this matter.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I do give you leave: is this your desire

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It is so.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Then be it so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: And now let your son prepare to fetch the bride. The other one shall be schooled in such language as befits children. But Syrus----

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What? If I live, I will have him so handsomely dressed, so well combed out, that he shall always remember me as long as he lives; to imagine that I'm to be a laughing-stock and a plaything for him! So may the Gods bless me! he would not have dared to do to a widow-woman the things which he has done to me.Which he has done to me: Colman has the following Note: "The departure of Menedemus here is very abrupt, seeming to be in the midst of a conversation; and his re-entrance with Clitipho, already supposed to be apprised of what has passed between the two old gentlemen, is equally precipitate. Menage imagines that some verses are lost here. Madame Dacier strains hard to defend the Poet, and fills up the void of time by her old expedient of making the Audience wait to see Chremes walk impatiently to and fro, till a sufficient time is elapsed for Menedemus to have given Clitipho a summary account of the cause of his father's anger. The truth is, that a too strict observance of the unity of place will necessarily produce such absurdities; and there are several other instances of the like nature in Terence." They go into their respective houses.

div2.stage: Enter MENEDEMUS, with CLITIPHO and SYRUS.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Prithee, is it really the fact, Menedemus, that my father can, in so short a space of time, have cast off all the natural affection of a parent for me? For what crime? What so great enormity have I, to my misfortune, committed? Young men generally do the same.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I am aware that this must be much more harsh and severe to you, on whom it falls; but yet I take it no less amiss than you. How it is so I know not, nor can I account for it, except that from my heart I wish you well.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Did not you say that my father was waiting here? Enter CHREMES from his house.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: See, here he is. MENEDEMUS goes into his house.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why are you blaming me, Clitipho? Whatever I have done in this matter, I had a view to you and your imprudence. When I saw that you were of a careless disposition, and held the pleasures of the moment of the first importance, and did not look forward to the future, I took measures that you might neither want nor be able to waste this which I have. When, through your own conduct, it was not allowed me to give it you, to whom I ought before all, I had recourse to those who were your nearest relations; to them I have made over and intrusted every thing.Intrusted every thing: This is an early instance of a trusteeship and a guardianship. There you'll always find a refuge for your folly; food, clothing, and a roof under which to betake yourself.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Ah me!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It is better than that, you being my heir, Bacchis should possess this estate of mine.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: apart. I'm ruined irrevocably!--Of what mischief have I, wretch that I am, unthinkingly been the cause?

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Would I were dead!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Prithee, first learn what it is to live. When you know that, if life displeases you, then try the other.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Master, may I be allowed----?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Say on.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: But may I safely?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Say on.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: What injustice or what madness is this, that that in which I have offended, should be to his detriment?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: It's all over.It's all over: "Ilicet," literally, "you may go away." This was the formal word with which funeral ceremonies and trials at law were concluded. Don't you mix yourself up in it; no one accuses you, Syrus, nor need you look out for an altar,Look out for an altar: He alludes to the practice of slaves taking refuge at altars when they had committed any fault, and then suing for pardon through a "precator" or "mediator." See the Mostellaria of Plautus, 1. 1074, where Tranio takes refuge at the altar from the vengeance of his master, Theuropides. or for an intercessor for yourself.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: What is your design?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I am not at all angry either with you, to SYRUS, or with you to CLITIPHO; nor is it fair that you should be so with me for what I am doing. He goes into his house.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: He's gone. I wish I had asked him----

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What, Syrus?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Where I am to get my subsistence; he has so utterly cast us adrift. You are to have it, for the present, at your sister's, I find.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Has it then come to this pass, Syrus--that I am to be in danger even of starving?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: So we only live, there's hope----

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What hope?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: That we shall be hungry enough.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Do you jest in a matter so serious, and not give me any assistance with your advice?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: On the contrary, I'm both now thinking of that, and have been about it all the time your father was speaking just now; and so far as I can perceive----

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: It will not be wanting long. He meditates.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What is it, then?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: It is this--I think that you are not their son.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: How's that, Syrus? Are you quite in your senses?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: I'll tell you what's come into my mind; be you the judge. While they had you alone, while they had no other source of joy more nearly to affect them, they indulged you, they lavished upon you. Now a daughter has been found, a pretense has been found in fact on which to turn you adrift.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: It's very probable.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: Do you suppose that he is so angry on account of this fault?

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: I do not think so.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
CLITIPHO
sp.p: You say true; what then shall I now do, Syrus?

sp.speaker: SYRUS
CLITIPHO
sp.p: You give good advice; I'll do so. He goes into the house of CHREMES.

sp.speaker: SYRUS
sp.p: to himself. Most fortunately did this come into my mind. For the less hope the young man entertains, the greater the difficulty with which he'll bring his father to his own terms. I'm not sure even, that he may not take a wife, and then no thanks for Syrus. But what is this? The old man's coming out of doors; I'll be off. What has so far happened, I am surprised at, that he didn't order me to becarried off from here: now I'll away to Menedemus here, I'll secure him as my intercessor; I can put no trust in our old man. Goes into the house of MENEDEMUS.

div2.stage: Enter CHREMES and SOSTRATA from the house.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Really, sir, if you don't take care, you'll be causing some mischief to your son; and indeed I do wonder at it, my husband, how anything so foolish could ever come into your head.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Oh, you persist in being the woman? Did I ever wish for any one thing in all my life, Sostrata, but that you were my contradicter on that occasion? And yet if I were now to ask you what it is that I have done amiss, or why you act thus, you would not know in what point you are now so obstinately opposing me in your folly.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I, not know?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Yes, rather, I should have said you do know; inasmuch as either expression amounts to the same thing.Amounts to the same thing: "Quam quidem redit ad integrum eadem oratio;" meaning, "it amounts to one and the same thing," or, "it is all the same thing," whether you do or whether you don't know.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Alas! you are unreasonable to expect me to be silent in a matter of such importance.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I don't expect it; talk on then, I shall still do it not a bit the less.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Will you do it?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Don't you see how much evil you will be causing by that course?--He suspects himself to be a foundling.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do you say so?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Assuredly it will be so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Admit it.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Hold now--prithee, let that be for our enemies. Am I to admit that he is not my son who really is?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What! are you afraid that you can not prove that he is yours, whenever you please?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Because my daughter has been found?Because my daughter has been found: This sentence has given much trouble to the Commentators. Colman has the following just remarks upon it: "Madame Dacier, as well as all the rest of the Commentators, has stuck at these words. Most of them imagine she means to say, that the discovery of Antiphila is a plain proof that she is not barren. Madame Dacier supposes that she intimates such a proof to be easy, because Clitipho and Antiphila were extremely alike; which sense she thinks immediately confirmed by the answer of Chremes. I can not agree with any of them, and think that the whole difficulty of the passage here, as in many other places, is entirely of their own making. Sostrata could not refer to the reply of Chremes, because she could not possibly tell what it would be; but her own speech is intended as an answer to his preceding one, which she takes as a sneer on her late wonderful discovery of a daughter; imagining that he means to insinuate that she could at any time with equal ease make out the proofs of the birth of her son. The elliptical mode of expression so usual with Terence, together with the refinements of Commentators, seem to have created all the obscurity."

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: No; but for a reason why it should be much sooner believed--because he is just like you in disposition, you will easily prove that he is your child; for he is exactly like you; why, he has not a single vice left him but you have just the same. Then, besides, no woman could have been the mother of such a son but yourself. But he's coming out of doors, and how demure! When you understand the matter, you may form your own conclusions.

div2.stage: Enter CLITIPHO from the house of CHREMES.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: If there ever was any time, mother, when I caused you pleasure, being called your son by your own desire, I beseech: you to remember it, and now to take compassion on me in my distress. A thing I beg and request--do discover to me my parents.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I conjure you, my son, not to entertain that notion in your mind, that you are another person's child.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Wretch that I am! Turning to CHREMES. Was it this that you wanted, pray? To CLITIPHO. So may you be the survivor of me and of him, you are my son and his; and henceforth, if you love me,take care that I never hear that speech from you again.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: But I say, if you fear me, take care how I find these propensities existing in you.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What propensities?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: If you wish to know, I'll tell you; being a trifler, an idler, a cheat, a glutton, a debauchee, a spendthrift--Believe me, and believe that you are our son.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: This is not the language of a parent.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p:
If you had been born from my head, Clitipho,just as they say Minerva was from Jove's, none the more on that account would I suffer myself to be disgraced by your profligacy.By your profligacy: It is probably this ebullition of Comic anger which is referred to by Horace, in his Art of Poetry:
Interdum tamen et vocem Comoedia tollit,
Iratusque Chremes tumido delitigat ore.
"Yet sometimes Comedy as well raises her voice, and enraged Chremes censures in swelling phrase."

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: May the Gods forbid it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I don't know as to the Gods;I don't know as to the Gods: "Deos nescio." The Critic Lambinus, in his letter to Charles the Ninth of France, accuses Terence of impiety in this passage. Madame Dacier has, however, well observed, that the meaning is not "I care not for the Gods," but "I know not what the Gods will do." so far as I shall be enabled, I will carefully prevent it. You are seeking that which you possess--parents; that which you are in want of you don't seek--in what way to pay obedience to a father, and to preserve what he acquired by his industry. That you by trickery should bring before my eyes----I am ashamed to mention the unseemly word in her presence pointing to SOSTRATA, but you were not in any degree ashamed to act thus.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: aside. Alas! how thoroughly displeased I now am with myself! How much ashamed! nor do I know how to make a beginning to pacify him.

div2.stage: Enter MENEDEMUS from his house.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: to himself. Why really, Chremes is treating his son too harshly and too unkindly. I'm come out, therefore, to make peace between them. Most opportunely I see them both.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Well, Menedemus, why don't you order my daughter to be sent for, and close with the offerAnd close with the offer: "Firmas." This ratification or affirmation would be made by Menedemus using the formal word "Accipio," "I accept." of the portion that I mentioned?

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: My husband, I entreat you not to do it.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Father, I entreat you to forgive me.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Forgive him, Chremes; do let then prevail upon you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Am I knowingly to make my property a present to Bacchis? I'll not do it.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Why, we would not suffer it.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: If you desire me to live, father, do forgive me.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Do, my dear Chremes.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: Come, Chremes, pray, don't be so obdurate.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What am I to do here? I see I am not allowed to carry this through, as I had intended.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: You are acting as becomes you.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: On this condition, then, I'll do it; if he does that which I think it right he should do.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Father, I'll do any thing; command me.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: You must take a wife.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Father----

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll hear nothing.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: I'll take it upon myself; he shall do so.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I don't hear any thing from him as yet.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: aside. I'm undone!

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Do you hesitate, Clitipho?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nay, just as he likes.

sp.speaker: MENEDEMUS
sp.p: He'll do it all.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: This course, while you are making a beginning, is disagreeable, and while you are unacquainted with it. When you have become acquainted with it, it will become easy.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: I'll do it, father.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: My son, upon my honor I'll give you that charming girl, whom you may soon become attached to, the daughter of our neighbor Phanocrata.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: What! that red-haired girl, with cat's eyes, freckled face,Freckled face: Many take "sparso ore" here to mean "wide-mouthed." Lemonnier thinks that must be the meaning, as he has analyzed the other features of her countenance. There is, however, no reason why he should not speak of her complexion; and it seems, not improbably, to have the same meaning as the phrase "os lentiginosum," "a freckled face." and hooked nose? I can not, father.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Heyday! how nice he is! You would fancy he had set his mind upon it.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I'll name another.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Why no--since I must marry, I myself have one that I should pretty nearly make choice of.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: Now, son, I commend you.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: The daughter of Archonides here.

sp.speaker: SOSTRATA
sp.p: I'm quite agreeable.

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: Father, this now remains.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: CLITIPHO
sp.p: I want you to pardon Syrus for what he has done for my sake.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Be it so. To the Audience. Fare you well, and grant us your applause.
